repnme.cdata!:
Maldives - The First and Second Education
            and Training Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This performance assessment report rates
            two projects in the Maldives: The Education and Training
            Project. For both projects, the project outcome is rated
            highly satisfactory. Institutional development is rated
            substantial, and project sustainability is likely. World
            Bank performance is rated satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance is rated highly satisfactory. A number of
            lessons were confirmed by these experiences. Although
            oft-repeated, it remains a truism that government commitment
            is critical for success. Projects often have components
            involving multiple ministries, but these can be successfully
            implemented when there is a strong stakeholder commitment to
            reform and when there is political and administrative
            commitment to setting and achieving high-quality standards.
            Second, beside academic qualifications, criteria for
            awarding fellowships should include work experience and
            activities indicating leadership ability. Third, while using
            well-trained and dedicated teachers as supervisors may
            significantly promote high achievement, it takes them out of
            the classroom and may undermine the purpose. Fourth,
            suitable incentives are needed to create a pool of qualified
            and effective teachers. Fifth, fellowship programs need
            components of cost recovery, clear prioritizing of local
            needs, and clear selection criteria to raise the
            population's confidence level regarding the
            impartiality of selections made. Sixth, training abroad may
            be more economical and efficient.

2075367.trustfund:
TF035885-SRI LANKA - GENERAL EDUCATION PROJECT,TF020761-AUSTRALIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST
            FUND (USD)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education and Training
            Project for Maldives were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project sustainability was likely, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:  a
            responsive national training and fellowship program should
            be better linked to economic priorities and should include
            private sector opportunities. The project has positively
            influenced a reduction on expatriate staff employed within
            the public sector. Community involvement in the planning and
            operation of a new a toll school increases commitment and
            assists with the resolution of arising problems. The formula
            of using periodic implementation consultants was more
            economical and a good approach for the on the-job training
            of project implementation unit (PIU) staff. Government
            realized that unless increased linkages existed between
            economic priorities and the fellowship allocations, the
            reduction of nationals kill shortages will be more
            difficult. It also noted that unless the private sector was
            able to obtain some access to training and fellowships the
            country's economic growth will remain slower.

docna.cdata!:
Maldives - Education And Training Project :
            Credit 1981 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Maldives - Education And Training
            Project : Credit 1981 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education and Training Project aims
            to alleviate the shortage of skilled manpower through the
            expansion and upgrading of secondary education. Specifically
            the project will : (i)  finance a national scholarship
            program of about 171 study-years of overseas fellowships for
            higher level training; (ii) upgrade the quality of upper
            secondary education at the Science Education Center through
            the provision 28 study years of fellowships, equipment and
            learning materials; (iii) create secondary education
            opportunities in the atolls through the establishment of a
            regional secondary school; and (iv) finance fellowships and
            experts to strengthen the planning capacity of the Ministry
            of Education, improve labor market information and undertake
            teacher issues studies. Expatriate advisors and fellowships
            will also be financed to assist project implementation.
